thread.title: Mets' Steven Matz receives injection for ailing back

author: Maria Guardado | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
title: Mets' Steven Matz receives injection for ailing back
text:
NEW YORK â€” Mets left-hander Steven Matz received an injection Saturday with the the hope that the treatment will help relieve his lingering back pain.
"Seems like that might be something that relaxes him a little bit, relaxes those muscles back there," manager Terry Collins said. "I haven't talked to him today yet, but hopefully that helps him a lot."
Matz was scratched from his last start against the Phillies after experiencing stiffness in his back as a result of a bad night's sleep . He hasn't pitched since Sept. 24, when he faced the Cincinnati Reds.
Matz had been projected to be the Mets' fourth starter in the playoffs, but his injury has put his availability for the NLDS in doubt. Still, the Mets aren't willing to rule Matz out yet, as they are waiting to see if he'll will be healthy enough to pitch in an instructional league game on Wednesday.

"We're going to try to use the instructional league," Collins said. "If he can't pitch Wednesday, there's a good chance he won't pitch. But if he can get an outing this week, or he can throw 90 to 100 pitches by midweek, he'll be okay."
If Matz's back heals in time for the NLDS, he could make his first major-league start in three weeks against the Los Angeles Dodgers in a potential elimination game or clinching scenario. Despite these potential circumstances, Collins expressed confidence in Matz's ability to deliver a strong postseason outing, even with the extended layoff.
"I'm not that concerned about it," Collins said. "I'm sure every manager realizes it's the playoffs. It's still baseball. Nothing changes. Steven Matz has pitched against the Los Angeles Dodgers and pitched very well in his second start. If we can get out there that we know he's physically able to pitch the way he's capable of, I don't care what the scenario is. This guy can go out there and pitch a good ball game. He's done it, as I've said before, these guys have all grown up pitching big games. But if Steven is physically ready to do it, it doesn't scare me to put him out there."
